dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so big news coming out of China, especially in the tech world. Jack Ma, you know, co-founder of Alibaba, has been in the headlines again.

Alibaba accepts the penalty with sincerity and will ensure its compliance with determination.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Punishing is a good word for it. They had this practice called "er xuan yi," which literally translates to "choose one of two." Basically, if you wanted to sell on Alibaba, you couldn't sell on *other* platforms.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Punishing is a good word for it. They had this practice called er xuan yi, which literally translates to choose one of two. Basically, if you wanted to sell on Alibaba, you couldn't sell on other platforms.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since 2015, Alibaba has been punishing merchants if they used rivals sites through a practice dubbed er xuan yi, which means choose one out of two.

dialogue_turns.text: Wow, so forcing exclusivity. That's pretty blatant, um, anti-competitive behavior. No wonder SAMR stepped in.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And this all comes amidst, like, broader regulatory scrutiny, doesn't it? I remember the whole Ant Group IPO being halted.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The penalty comes amid intense regulatory scrutiny on the business empire built by Alibabas cofounder Jack Ma. In November, Chinas regulators abruptly halted the initial public offering of Ant Group, Alibabas fintech affiliate, just days before its shares were expected to begin trading in Shanghai and Hong Kong.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ma, a former English teacher who became one of Chinas internet pioneers, became the focus of regulators scrutiny following a speech at a summit in Shanghai in late October when he declared that Chinas regulatory restrictions were hampering innovation.
